##Background

Using devices such as Jawbone Up, Nike FuelBand, and Fitbit it is now possible to collect a large amount of data about personal activity relatively inexpensively. These type of devices are part of the quantified self movement â€“ a group of enthusiasts who take measurements about themselves regularly to improve their health, to find patterns in their behavior, or because they are tech geeks. One thing that people regularly do is quantify how much of a particular activity they do, but they rarely quantify how well they do it. In this project, goal will be to use the data from accelerometers on the belt, forearm, arm, and dumbell of 6 participants. They were asked to perform barbell lifts correctly and incorrectly in 5 different ways. More information is available from the website here: <http://groupware.les.inf.puc-rio.br/har> (see the section on the Weight Lifting Exercise Dataset). 

###Data 

The training data for this project are available here: 

<https://d396qusza40orc.cloudfront.net/predmachlearn/pml-training.csv>

The test data are available here: 

<https://d396qusza40orc.cloudfront.net/predmachlearn/pml-testing.csv>

The data for this project come from this source: <http://groupware.les.inf.puc-rio.br/har>. 


###Project Submission

The goal of the project is to predict the manner in which they did the excercise. This is the "classe" variable in the training set. A report created based on how the model was built, use of cross validation, choices taken, etc. Also have to use predication model to predict 20 different test cases.

1. Submit the githhub link with R markdown and compiled HTML file describing the analysis. 

2. Also apply machine learning algorithm to the 20 test cases available in the test data above.

```r
plot(subTraining$classe, col="blue", main="Bar Plot of levels of the variable classe within the subTraining data set", xlab="classe levels", ylab="Frequency")
```

![Rplot23](Rplot23.png)

From the graph above, we can see that each level frequency is within the same order of magnitude of each other. Level A is the most frequent with more than 4000 occurrences while level D is the least frequent with about 2500 occurrences.

####Decision Tree

```r
model1 <- rpart(classe ~ ., data=subTraining, method="class")
prediction1 <- predict(model1, subTesting, type = "class")
rpart.plot(model1, main="Classification Tree", extra=102, under=TRUE, faclen=0)
```

![Rplot24](Rplot24.png)

```r
confusionMatrix(prediction1, subTesting$classe)
```

pml_write_files = function(x){
  n = length(x)
  for(i in 1:n){
    filename = paste0("problem_id_",i,".txt")
    write.table(x[i],file=filename,quote=FALSE,row.names=FALSE,col.names=FALSE)
  }
}
